questions.text: Slow waves are generated by:
questions.solution:
The interstitial cells of Cajal undergo cyclic changes in membrane potential due to unique ion channels that peri­odically open and produce inward (pacemaker) currents that generate slow-wave activity.

Interstitial cells of Cajal are the pacemaker cells of the GIT that initiate the basic electrical rhythm (BER). These are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features.

In the stomach and the small intestine, these cells are located in the circular smooth muscle layer near the myenteric plexus. In the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer.

The slow waves usually do not by themselves cause muscle contraction in most parts of the gastrointestinal tract, except perhaps in the stomach. Instead, they mainly excite the appearance of intermittent spike potentials, and the spike potentials in turn actually excite the muscle contraction.

Note: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal.

questions.text: Least frequency of slow waves is seen in:
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the least frequency of slow waves is seen in the stomach (4/min).

The Basal electrical rhythm (BER) also called slow-wave, is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle. It is initiated by the interstitial cells of Cajal. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65mV and -45mV.

The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach.

The rate of BER in various sites is as follows:

  • Stomach: 4/min
  • Duodenum: 12/min
  • Distal ileum: 8/min
  • Cecum: 2/min
  • Sigmoid colon: 6/min

The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension.

Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension. Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

Muscle contraction can occur only when the motor stimulus is provided during the depolarisation part of the BER.

Thus, BER does not cause muscle contraction by itself, but controls the rate and organization sites of the muscle contractions, as in coordination of the peristaltic activity and setting the rhythm of segmentation.

questions.text: Slow waves are maximum in which part of the intestine?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the frequency of 'slow waves' is maximum in the ileum (8/min).

Normal intestinal motility is determined by two patterns of electrical activity - slow waves and spike potentials.

Slow waves, also known as basic electrical rhythm are partial depolarizations of smooth muscle cells, spreading along the GIT. They originate from the interstitial cells of Cajal. The smooth muscles are in a hyperpolarized state, having a resting membrane potential of -50 to -60mV.

These waves are not action potentials themselves and they do not cause any contractions. Slow waves raise the membrane potential by 5-15mV, bringing it closer to the threshold enabling spike potential (true action potential) to occur. Therefore, they set the basic rhythm of GIT.

questions.text: Chyme is propelled forward in small intestine by_______
questions.solution:
Chyme is propelled forward in the intestine by the peristaltic movement.

Chyme is a thick semifluid mass of partially digested food and digestive secretions that is expelled by the stomach into the duodenum.

Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front.

Segmentation consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward. 

It is the small intestine’s primary method of motility during digestion of a meal.

Migrating motor complexes (MMC) are the peristaltic motor patterns that occur during fasting. They migrate from the stomach to the distal ileum.

Haustrations are the characteristic saclike segments seen in the large intestine.

Related Pearl: Types of gastrointestinal motility

questions.text: Which of the following is the major initiating response for peristalsis?
questions.solution:
The major initiating response for peristalsis is local stretching of the gut.

Peristalsis is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. It occurs in all parts of the gastrointestinal tract from the esophagus to the rectum.

The stretch initiates a circular contraction behind the stimulus and an area of relaxation in front of it. The wave of contraction then moves in an oral-to-caudal direction. This propels the contents of the lumen forward at rates that vary from 2 to 25 cm/s.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in a patient on parasympathetic stimulation?
questions.solution:
Parasympathetic stimulation results in increased peristalsis.

Generally, the stimulation of parasympathetic nerves (PNS) causes an increase in the activity of the entire enteric nervous system. This, in turn, enhances the activity of most gastrointestinal functions.

PNS stimulation causes:

  • Contraction of smooth muscle in the wall
  • Relaxation of sphincters
  • ↑ Salivary secretion
  • ↑ Gastric secretion
  • ↑ Pancreatic secretion

SNS stimulation causes:

  • Relaxation of smooth muscle in the wall
  • Contraction of sphincters

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?
questions.solution:
VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine.

Peristalsis involves the contraction of a segment of intestine behind the bolus of food and relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus of food.

Cholinergic neurons passing in anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus.

Cholinergic neurons passing in retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

Note: In achalasia cardia, there is decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of the esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitters acts on the muscle, behind a bolus of food, in the process of peristalsis?
questions.solution:
Substance P and acetylcholine are released from neurons behind the bolus of food, causing smooth muscle contraction, which propels the food downwards.

NO and VIP are released by neurons in the anterograde direction from the bolus which produces relaxation in front of the stimulus.

questions.text: Gastric emptying is mainly regulated by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Gastric emptying is mainly regulated by enteric reflexes.

Regulation of gastric emptying is mainly by the inhibitory feedback signals from the duodenum that includes enterogastric reflex and hormonal feedback by cholecystokinin.

Enterogastric reflex: When food enters the duodenum, multiple nervous reflexes are initiated from the duodenal wall. They strongly inhibit the pyloric pump propulsive contractions and increase the tone of the pyloric sphincter.

These reflexes are mediated by three routes:

  • Directly from the duodenum to the stomach through the enteric nervous system in the gut wall (major role)
  • Through inhibitory sympathetic nerve fibers to the stomach (minor role)
  • Vagus nerves to the brain stem where they inhibit the normal excitatory signals transmitted to the stomach (minor role)

Hormonal feedback: Cholecystokinin is released from the mucosa of the jejunum in response to fatty substances in the chyme. This hormone acts as an inhibitor to block increased stomach motility caused by gastrin.

questions.text: Which among the following increases gastric emptying?
questions.solution:
The distension of the stomach increases gastric emptying.

Distension activates the mechanoreceptors that trigger long and short reflexes in the stomach. This increases the force of antral contraction and gastric emptying.

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?
questions.solution:
In the enterogastric reflex, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum.

When the food enters the duodenum, multiple reflexes are initiated from the duodenal wall which passes back to the stomach. These reflexes slow or stop the stomach emptying if the volume of the chyme in the duodenum becomes too much. These reflexes are called enterogastric reflexes.

This reflex can be triggered due to the following reasons:

  • Presence of irritants and acids in duodenal chyme (most sensitive factor)
  • Distension of duodenum due to the presence of an excessive volume of chyme
  • Rapid entry of hypertonic or hypotonic fluids into the duodenum
  • Presence of breakdown products of protein digestion and sometimes fat

questions.text: Enterogastric inhibitory reflexes are stimulated by all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Enterogastric inhibitory reflexes are stimulated by acidic contents, not alkaline.

The duodenal factors that can initiate enterogastric inhibitory reflexes (enterogastric reflexes) are:

  • Distention of the duodenum
  • Presence of any irritation of the duodenal mucosa
  • Acidity of the duodenal chyme
  • Osmolality of the chyme - either hypotonic or hypertonic fluid initiate enterogastric inhibitory reflexes. Thus, the flow of non-isotonic fluids into the small intestine is regulated. This prevents rapid changes in electrolyte concentrations in the extracellular fluid during the absorption of the intestinal contents.
  • Presence of certain breakdown products in the chyme, especially proteins and to a lesser extent, of fats

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her infant to the OPD for advice regarding nutrition. She says, soon after every meal, her kid defecates. What is the cause of colonic contraction in this situation?
questions.solution:
The cause of colonic contraction in the given situation is due to gastrocolic reflex.

Distension of the stomach by food initiates contractions of the rectum and frequently, a desire to defecate. This response is called the gastrocolic reflex. Because of this response, defecation after meals is common in children. This response may be amplified by the action of gastrin on the colon.

questions.text: The following image shows which type of GI motility?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the migrating motor complex.

The image shows 3 phases: 

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

This occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in the aboral direction at the rate of 5 cm/min. Its main function is to clear intestinal contents and prepare for the next meal.

Option A: Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front.

Option B: Segmentation and mixing help in mixing intestinal contents with digestive juices and provides time for digestion and absorption.  

It consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward.

Option D: Basal Electrical Rhythm is fluctuation in the resting membrane potential of smooth muscle cells of the intestine as shown below.

questions.text: Migrating motor complexes occurs at the rate of _______  and at an interval of  _________
questions.solution:
Migrating motor complex (MMC) migrates from the stomach to the distal ileum at a rate of about 5 cm/min and also occurs at intervals of approximately 100 minutes.

MMC is a type of gastrointestinal motility that occurs during fasting between periods of digestion. It is initiated by motilin. It helps to clear the stomach and small intestine of luminal contents in preparation for the next meal. Gastric secretion, bile flow, and pancreatic secretion increase during each MMC.

After ingestion of a meal, secretion of motilin is suppressed and the MMC is abolished.

Each cycle of MMC has 3 phases

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

Note: Disorders of MMC have been associated with gastroparesis, intestinal pseudo-obstruction, and small intestinal bacterial overgrowth.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about gastroduodenal motor activity?

choices.text: Migrating motor complex/MMC in the fasting state lasts for 50 minutes
Duodenal slow waves are limited to the duodenum
From the duodenum, the MMC moves distally at 5-10 cm/min
The amplitude of contraction decreases to a minimum in phase III of MMC

questions.solution:
From the duodenum, the migrating motor complex (MMC) moves distally at 5–10 cm/min, reaching the terminal ileum after 1.5 hours. 

In the fasting state,  there is a period of quiescence in the small bowel, lasting for approximately 40 minutes (phase I). This is followed by a series of waves, also lasting for about 40 minutes, propagating from the fundus of the stomach in a caudal direction at a rate of about 3 per minute (phase II). 

Duodenal slow waves are generated in the duodenum at a rate of about 10 per minute, which carry down the small bowel.

The amplitude of these contractions increases to a maximum in phase III, which lasts for about 10 minutes. This 90-minute cycle of activity is then repeated.

questions.text: Which of the following does not increase small intestinal motility?
questions.solution:
Secretin inhibits small intestinal motility.

Factors that increase the peristaltic activity of the small intestine:

  • Hormonal - gastrin, CCK, insulin, motilin, and serotonin.
  • Neural - duodenal distension by chyme, gastroenteric reflexes, gastroileal reflexes, parasympathetic (Ach) stimulation.

Factors that decrease the peristaltic activity of the small intestine:

  • Hormonal - secretin and glucagon.
  • Neural - sympathetic stimulation.

Gastroileal reflex - On reaching the ileocecal valve, the chyme is sometimes blocked for several hours until the person eats another meal. At that time, a gastroileal reflex intensifies peristalsis in the ileum and forces the remaining chyme through the ileocecal valve into the cecum of the large intestine.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing sigmoidoscopy as a part of his routine colon cancer screening. While doing the procedure, the rectum is inflated with gas. Which part of the intestine would you likely see increased peristalsis in this patient?
questions.solution:
While doing sigmoidoscopy if the rectum is inflated with gas, increased peristalsis is seen in the distal colon.

The distention of the rectal wall initiates afferent signals. These signals spread through the myenteric plexus to initiate peristaltic waves in the descending colon, sigmoid (distal colon), and rectum.

questions.text: Which of the following controls the secretions of GIT?
questions.solution: Secretions of GIT are controlled by the Meissner plexus.

questions.text: You will feel the first urge to defecate when rectal pressure is increased to:
questions.solution:
The first urge to defecate occurs when rectal pressure is increased to 18 mm Hg.

When this pressure reaches 55 mm Hg, the external and the internal sphinc­ter relax, and there is reflex expulsion of the contents of the rectum.

Defecation reflex: Distension of the rectum and colon stimulates stretch receptors in the rectal wall. Then, the defecation reflexes travel from the colon and rectum to the spinal cord and back again to produce the powerful colonic, rectal, and abdominal contractions required for defecation.
